newsitem.title: NIGERIA: Nigeria LNG expects $357 million revenue. [CORRECTED 01:45 GMT 5/11]
newsitem.headline: Nigeria LNG expects $357 million revenue. [CORRECTED 01:45 GMT 5/11]

text.p: Nigeria's Liquefied Natural Gas (NLNG) said on Friday it expected to earn $357 million from interest (Corrects time frame) on its deposits in foreign accounts and vessels it has put on term charter.
"Three of the vessels acquired are operating in the Far East, while shareholders funds are in escrow account," NLNG chief executive Theo Oerlemans told a news conference.
Shareholders' funds in the $4 billion project, the biggest in Africa, amount to $2.873 billion, which Oerlemans said had been fully paid up.
The shareholders are state-owned Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation, Shell Gas BV, Elf Aquitaine and Agip SpA.
Those that have signed long-term contracts to buy the Nigerian LNG are Enel of Italy, Enargas of Spain and Gaz de France.
The project involves building a plant to produce 7.2 billion cubic metres of LNG per annum, beginning in 1999.
Nigeria, which has 10 times more gas than crude oil, has mooted the idea of an LNG plant for the last 25 years.
Oerlemans said shipment of the first LNG cargo would take place in the third quarter of 1999. "All the buyers except Enel of Italy have their terminals ready to receive the gas," he added.
Enel is having problems getting the Italian government to approve siting the terminal at Monfalcone. Another option for it is to site the terminal at Montalto di Castro.
"Enel will still have to pay for the gas as agreed in the sale contract," Oerlemans said, adding that the contract provided for no right of termination.
Lou Pucher, project director of TSKJ, the consortium handling the LNG plant, said construction work was heading for 25 percent completion by the end of 1996.
"We are now engaging 600 people at the plant site," Pucher said, adding that peak labour force would reach 6,000 by 1999.
The TSKJ group comprises Technip of France, Snamprogetti of Italy, M.W. Kellogg, part of Dresser Industries of the United States, and JGC Corp of Japan.
